title: Largest Lakes by Surface Area
subtitle: Major terrestrial lakes over 3,000 km², ranked by area.

data.name: Caspian Sea
data.notes: Geologically a small ocean rather than a lake. Garabogazköl lagoon, if counted separately, would rank as the world's 15th largest, with an area of 18,000 square kilometres (6,900 sq mi).

data.name: Superior
data.notes: Largest of the Great Lakes by volume, having more water than the other four combined.

data.name: Victoria
data.notes: The largest lake by area in Africa.

data.name: Huron
data.notes: The larger lobe of Lake Michigan–Huron. Contains Manitoulin Island, the world's largest lake island.

data.name: Michigan
data.notes: The smaller lobe of Lake Michigan–Huron. The largest lake (by area) that is located entirely in one country.

data.name: Tanganyika
data.countries_with_shorelines: Tanzania, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Burundi, Zambia
data.notes: Longest freshwater lake in the world and third largest of any kind by volume.

data.name: Baikal
data.notes: Deepest lake in the world and largest freshwater lake in the world by volume.

data.name: Great Bear Lake
data.notes: Largest lake entirely within Canada, and the largest lake partially within the Arctic Circle

data.name: Malawi (Nyasa)
data.notes: Has more species of fish than any other lake in the world.

data.name: Great Slave Lake
data.notes: Deepest lake in North America

data.name: Erie
data.notes: Has the smallest volume of the Great Lakes.

data.name: Winnipeg
data.notes: Very large catchment area compared to own size. No other great lake has that ratio.

data.name: Ontario
data.notes: The lowest lying of the Great Lakes.

data.name: Ladoga
data.notes: Largest lake in Europe.

data.name: Balkhash
data.notes: Fresh shallow western part. Salty deeper eastern part. Shrinking in size.

data.name: Vostok
data.notes: Largest lake in Antarctica, but subglacial.

data.name: Onega
data.notes: Second-largest lake in Europe.

data.name: Titicaca
data.notes: Highest navigable lake in the world. Greatest mountain lake too. Largest lake in South America.

data.name: Nicaragua
data.notes: Largest lake in Central America. Contains fresh water sharks.

data.name: Athabasca
data.notes: A remnant of the vast, Glacial Lake McConnell. Huge catchment area (ratio).

data.name: Reindeer
data.notes: The deepest areas are the site of a large meteorite impact, which happened almost 100 million years ago. Much older than the lake.

data.name: Turkana
data.notes: Largest permanent desert lake and the world's largest alkaline lake.

data.name: Issyk-Kul
data.notes: Second largest mountain lake in the world. Second deepest saline lake as well.

data.name: Vänern
data.notes: Largest lake in the European Union.

data.name: Rukwa
data.notes: Tanzania's 4th largest lake.

data.name: Albert
data.countries_with_shorelines: Uganda Democratic Republic of the Congo

data.name: Nettilling
data.notes: Largest lake on an island; Baffin Island.

data.name: Winnipegosis
data.notes: Second largest lake in Manitoba.

data.name: Mweru
data.countries_with_shorelines: Zambia Democratic Republic of the Congo
data.notes: The second largest lake in the Congo's drainage basin, Tanganyika being the largest.

data.name: Nipigon
data.notes: Largest lake entirely in Ontario. Part of the Great Lake drainage basin. Often referred to as the, "sixth" or "seventh" lake, together with St. Clair.

data.name: Manitoba
data.notes: A remnant of the prehistoric, Glacial Lake Agassiz together with: Winnipeg and Winnipegosis.

data.name: Taymyr
data.notes: Largest lake entirely within the Arctic Circle.

data.name: Qinghai
data.notes: Largest lake in China. Variable in size. Endorheic basin.

data.name: Saimaa
data.notes: Largest catchment area of the lakes within the Nordic countries.

data.name: Lake of the Woods
data.notes: About 15 000 islands. The shoreline measures (included these) roughly: 105 000 km.

data.name: Khanka
data.notes: Has a shape like a pear. Variable size. Drains through the Amur River, that ends in the Sea of Japan.

data.name: Sarygamysh
data.notes: Located about midway between the Caspian Endorheic basin and former Aral Sea. No drainage river today. Drained centuries ago to the Caspian Sea (Uzboy River). Polluted.

data.name: Dubawnt
data.notes: Frozen surface 10 months each year. No permanent settlements on its shores.

data.name: Van
data.notes: Largest lake in the Middle East. Third deepest saline lake.

data.name: Peipus
data.notes: Largest trans-boundary lake in Europe.

data.name: Uvs
data.notes: Greatest lake in Mongolia (by area). Very large catchment area (endorheic).

data.name: North Aral Sea
data.notes: Largest remnant of the former Aral Sea. Once the world's third largest lake.

data.name: Poyang
data.notes: Largest fresh water lake in China. Variable size. Important location for the birdlife.

data.name: Tana
data.notes: The source of the Blue Nile.

data.name: Amadjuak
data.notes: In geological terms, a "young" lake (approximately 4,500 years old). Second largest on Baffin Island, third largest in Nunavut.

data.name: Melville
data.type: Saline 1.95% (approx. average of surface and bottom water)
data.notes: Estuary connected with the Atlantic Ocean. Large drainage basin in the Labrador.

data.name: Bangweulu
data.notes: One of the world's great wetland systems. The area has swamps and floodplain. Variable size on this shallow lake. Crucial importance for animals and birds, of a far larger area.
